awd_titl_txt: S&AS: INT: COLLAB: Autonomy as a Service
awd_abstract_narration:
How can one deploy teams of autonomous robots over long periods of time in such a way that they can be recruited and tasked by operators to perform a wide variety of tasks? Examples of such tasks include the environmental monitoring tasks encountered in biological conservation applications or in precision agriculture. This project will address this issue by letting the autonomous robots be available to the user in an on-demand manner through a novel 'Autonomy as a service' framework. To realize this idea, new tools will be developed for (i) describing the tasks in a way that can be understood by the robots, (ii) ensuring that the robots stay safe while executing the tasks, and (iii) methods for the robots to learn and improve over time in combination with the ability to assess their performance. The broader impact from the project will include implications for environmental monitoring, outreach programs for increasing STEM participation, and an integration of the research findings into the curriculum at the three participating institutions (Georgia Tech, BU, and MIT). 

In detail, the three main research themes are: (i) From Specification to Execution: The users must be able to recruit and task the robots with new missions, which calls for formally correct ways of going from high-level specifications, formulated as Linear Temporal Logic formulae, to coordinated control programs for the robots to execute. (ii) Resilient Autonomy: When delivering a system that can be commanded to perform tasks over long periods of time, the first concern must be to preserve the integrity of the system itself, i.e., basic functionality must be ensured even as the robot team is recruited to perform a particular set of tasks. This project will achieve this through the use of composable barrier certificates that ensure the forward invariance of the safe set, i.e., if the robots start safe, they will stay safe. (iii) Trajectory Based Learning from Massive Data Sets: The agent team must be able to assess the performance of whatever it is that they are monitoring. In this project, this will be achieved through models that can be effectively learned from massive data sets through novel tools for data compression and representation.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering

por.por_cntn:
Autonomy as a service refers to the ability of a group of autonomous robots, deployed in an environment over a sustained period of time, to be recruited and commanded to perform a wide variety of tasks in response to user specifications, while ensuring that the basic integrity of the system is preserved. In this project we investigate what this concept entails scientifically in the context of sustained and persistent monitoring tasks. Consider, for example, a scenario where a number of aerial vehicles are to monitor a marine area. The baseline operation of these vehicles is to provide persistent coverage of the area ? formalized through a temporal logic specification ? while ensuring that the integrity of the team is maintained. This latter consideration concerns (i) ensuring safe operations of the vehicles, (ii) the need to refuel when energy levels are low, and (iii) the ability to communicate potential findings back to a base station. We formulate these three considerations as a resilience constraint that must be formally composed with the baseline specification. At the same time, the team can be redirected to perform other tasks ? hence the autonomy as a service label ? such as monitoring incoming ship traffic, including the detection of anomalies among the ships. Anomaly detection, in turn, involves the composition of additional specifications as well as learning behavior models of the monitored objects from observed trajectories. This way of composing baseline tasks, resilience requirements, new missions, and learned behaviors is key to the autonomy as a service concept as it translates across a number of related application domains, such as precision agriculture where autonomous ground-air teams must monitor the crop to determine watering, pesticide, or fertilizer needs, or environmental monitoring where vehicles are embedded in the environment over sustained periods of time while measuring evolving environmental conditions.

This project contributed several novel solutions for compressing trained neural network models. The solutions are applicable to a wider range of model architectures and have significant impact on the performance of the solutions. Our work shows that up to 90% of the parameters of a model can be pruned without significant impact on the accuracy of the network. Sparsifying large-scale models with performance guarantees enables faster learning at scale. Additionally, we have used the basic methodology used for sparsification to create a privacy-preserving, decryption-based solution for classification called K-in nearest neighbors clustering. We have also used the same methodology to learn the logic structure of tasks and their supporting finite state automata for decision making.

Four PhD students who contributed to this project received their PhDs in 2021.


Last Modified: 12/05/2021
Modified by: Daniela Rus
